forecast.review:
- New/useful from Forecaster 2: The Curtice point about Reform’s thinly spread support under FPTP and the concrete UKIP benchmark (17 seats in 2013) sharpen the structural case against a Reform plurality. That reinforces my prior concerns about vote efficiency and slate coverage. I also agree the Electoral Calculus output is likely a model rather than a true local poll and may assume full candidate coverage.
- On Forecaster 3: I agree national Conservative collapse and volatility make big moves plausible, and the KentOnline/Electoral Calculus call can’t be ignored. But assigning 45% seems to over-weight a single model and under-weight organizational constraints (candidate slate, ground game) and the multi-party competition in Kent (Labour/LD/Greens) that will convert a fragmented right into non-Reform wins. 
- Net: The added Curtice/UKIP precedent supports a lower, not higher, probability. Nothing here provides concrete evidence that Reform has a near-full credible slate across Kent or a strong local ground game—key prerequisites for a plurality.
forecast.rationale:
- Baseline: 81 seats; Conservatives held 57 in 2021. To be largest, Reform likely needs 25–35 seats depending on fragmentation. The best analogous performance (UKIP 2013) was 17 seats, with a stronger local footprint than Reform currently appears to have.
- Structural headwinds for Reform: first-past-the-post inefficiency for broadly distributed support; historically incomplete candidate coverage in locals; lower-propensity voters in local elections; and entrenched Labour/Lib Dem presence in many urban/west Kent divisions. These factors make it more likely the anti-Conservative vote converts to Labour/LD/Green seats rather than a Reform plurality.
- The Electoral Calculus ‘poll’ is almost certainly a model that can misestimate seat conversion if it assumes uniform swing and full slates. With only days to go, if Reform had fielded a near-complete slate and was leading multiple local polls, we’d likely have clearer corroboration.
- Upside scenario exists (Conservative collapse, Reform tops coastal/rural divisions with full slate), but remains a tail relative to the structural constraints and competition from Labour/LDs. Given this, and reinforced by Forecaster 2’s arguments, I do not see reason to move higher.
- I would move up if credible evidence shows Reform is running a near-full slate with strong on-the-ground campaigns in key divisions and corroborating local polling; I would move down if slate coverage is patchy or there’s clear Labour/LD targeting gains.
- Conclusion: Maintain a low but non-trivial probability.
